para.paratext: The phrase “burden of proof” is ambiguous;[1] it is used indiscriminately to refer either to the burden of persuasion or to the burden of producing evidence.[2] It is so used in the Georgia statutes.[3]

The term “burden of proof” is usually used to refer to the burden of persuasion.[4] However, the interchangeable usage of the terms may well result in confusion and cause the trial judge to give an incorrect charge.[5] This chapter will use the terms burden of persuasion and burden of producing evidence for clarity.

The burden of persuasion is the duty of establishing the issues in the case. The burden of producing evidence is the duty of going forward with the presentation of evidence or of making a prima facie case. Statutory and judicial considerations of the burdens usually assume a definition of the terms. Each burden is referred to in the context of the particular problem involved.
The burden of persuasion is fixed once and does not shift. The burden of producing evidence may shift several times during a trial.[6]

The burden of producing evidence is procedural and a failure to carry it will result in a termination of the case. The party with the burden of persuasion cannot prevail unless he carries that burden. This will be considered later in connection with the weight of the evidence necessary to carry the burdens.

By statute, the burden of persuasion in criminal cases is “whether there is sufficient evidence to satisfy the mind and conscience beyond a reasonable doubt.”[7] In civil cases, the plaintiff must generally prove its overall case “by a preponderance of the evidence.” “The standard requires only that the finder of fact be inclined by the evidence toward one side or the other.”[8]

Trial courts often attempt to further define or clarify a particular burden for the jury. The Georgia Supreme Court held that a court might properly define the burden of “beyond a reasonable doubt” because “the State is not required to prove the guilt of the accused beyond all doubt or to a mathematical certainty,” and that “[m]oral and reasonable certainty is all that can be expected in a legal investigation.”[9]

In Pilcher v. State,[10] the trial court instructed the jury “the State is not required to prove the guilt of the accused beyond all doubt or to a mathematical certainty.” On appeal, the defendant argued that the mathematical terminology added by the court lessened the degree of proof necessary to convict by suggesting to the jury that something less than “beyond a reasonable doubt” would be sufficient. The Court of Appeals rejected this argument, relying on United States Supreme Court precedent, which held that “taken as a whole,” an instruction that mathematical certainty is not required for conviction “correctly conveyed the concept of reasonable doubt to the jury.”[11]

In Zwiren v. Thompson,[12] the trial court charged the jury that the plaintiff must prove, “within a reasonable degree of medical certainty,” that malpractice caused his injuries before he could recover damages. The Georgia Supreme Court held that “the charge as given, while not a model of clarity, did not rise to the level of reversible error.” Clearly, in a medical malpractice case (as a civil action), the plaintiff must prove liability by a “preponderance of the evidence.” However, confusion in this burden of proof occurs because, in order to establish proximate cause by a preponderance of the evidence in a medical malpractice action, the plaintiff must establish that there was “reasonable medical probability” or “reasonable medical certainty” that the negligence caused the injury. In Zwiren, the Court suggested the following jury instruction:

In order for the plaintiff to show that the defendant's alleged negligence was the proximate cause of the plaintiff's injury, the plaintiff must present expert medical testimony. An expert's opinion on the issue of whether the defendant's alleged negligence caused the plaintiff's injury cannot be based on speculation or possibility. It must be based on reasonable medical probability or reasonable medical certainty. If you find that the expert's testimony regarding causation is not based on reasonable medical probability or reasonable medical certainty, then the plaintiff has not proven that the plaintiff's injury was proximately caused by the defendant's alleged negligence, and you would return a verdict for the defendant.[13]

However, Justices Hunstein and Carley joined Justice Sears' dissent, which disapproved of the charge and the confusion created by instructing jurors that there are alternate or conflicting standards that apply to the causation issue in malpractice cases. The dissent argued:

In medical malpractice cases, the plaintiff is required to bring forth expert evidence of causation which shows that “there was a reasonable probability that the negligence caused the injury.” … In this appeal, the charge at issue instructed that the plaintiff was required to bring forth a preponderance of evidence to establish causation to “a medical certainty.” As such, the charge clearly placed a greater evidentiary burden on the plaintiff, something which this Court has previously cautioned against in civil cases.[14]

The dissent thus agreed with the majority's position that expert witnesses are free to express their opinions in terms of medical certainty but stated that this freedom should not affect a trial court's jury charge—the various types of testimony offered during trials cannot provide a basis for changing the controlling standards of proof in these trials.[15]

Even where the trial judge used the term “burden of proof” improperly in his charge, the Georgia Court of Appeals held that he meant the burden of going forward or of producing evidence and this was not error. Glover v. Department of Transp., 166 Ga. App. 512, 304 S.E.2d 567 (1983).
